excerpt: Museum in 16th- & 21st-century buildings housing more than 800 works, some with links to the island.
detail_description: Es Baluard Museu d'Art Contemporani de Palma is a must-visit museum in Palma, housed in 16th- and 21st-century buildings. It features over 800 works with connections to the island, showcasing contemporary art pieces from artists like Cezanne, Gauguin, Picasso, Miro, Magritte, Polke, Barcelo and Schnabel.
name: Es Baluard Museu d'Art Contemporani de Palma
address: Plaça de la Porta de Santa Catalina, 10, Centre, 07012 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: Palma is a resort city and capital of the Spanish island of Mallorca (Majorca), in the western Mediterranean. The massive Santa María cathedral, a Gothic landmark begun in the 13th century, overlooks the Bay of Palma. The adjacent Almudaina is a Moorish-style Arab fortress converted to a royal residence. West of the city, hilltop Bellver Castle is a medieval fortress with a distinctive circular shape.
detail_description: Palma, the capital of Mallorca in the western Mediterranean, is a resort city known for its rich history and stunning landmarks. The Gothic Santa María cathedral and the Moorish-style Almudaina fortress are just a few examples of its architectural wonders. This vibrant city is considered one of the most beautiful in the Mediterranean, offering a mix of history, culture, and culinary delights.
name: Palma
address: Balearic Islands, Spain

excerpt: Originally an Arabian fort, this grand palace is used by the Royal Family for various events.
detail_description: The Royal Palace of La Almudaina, a stunning blend of history and architecture, is located in Palma, right next to the iconic cathedral. Originally an Arabian fort, it was transformed into a royal residence by King Jaume after the Christian conquest in 1229. This magnificent palace serves as one of the official residences for the Spanish royal family and showcases various areas open to visitors.
name: Royal Palace of La Almudaina
address: Carrer del Palau Reial, s/n, Centre, 07001 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

detail_description: Mercat de Santa Catalina is a must-visit undercover food market in the trendy Santa Catalina neighborhood. It's recommended to explore it after sunset, as the area comes alive with its thriving nightlife, featuring trendy bars, clubs, and contemporary restaurants. The market offers a variety of local delicacies such as sobrassada sausage, olive oil, meats, cheeses, wines, and liqueurs. You can also find stalls selling oils, chutneys, honey, and other packaged goods.
name: Mercat de Santa Catalina
address: Plaça de la Navegació, s/n, Ponent, 07013 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: The former fishing barrio of Santa Catalina is a hip enclave centered on a centuries-old market piled with local produce. Leafy streets lined by gaily painted cottages and art nouveau mansions are packed with design boutiques and vintage stores. Martini lounges and music cafes sit alongside dive bars popular with a bohemian crowd, while trendy restaurants serving global cuisines occupy squares and backstreet alleys.
detail_description: Santa Catalina, a former fishing neighborhood, has transformed into a trendy area with a vibrant market offering local produce. The streets are adorned with colorful cottages and art nouveau mansions, hosting design boutiques and vintage stores. This hip enclave features martini lounges, music cafes, and dive bars attracting a bohemian crowd. Additionally, trendy restaurants serving global cuisines can be found in squares and backstreet alleys.
name: Santa Catalina
address: Ponent District, Palma, Balearic Islands, Spain

excerpt: 1300s circular castle set on a wooded hilltop overlooking Palma, home to the city's history museum.
detail_description: Castell de Bellver, a 14th-century circular castle commissioned by James II of Aragon, sits atop a wooded hill overlooking Palma. Initially built as a royal residence, it later served as a military prison. Today, the castle houses the City History Museum showcasing Mallorca's history through various artifacts and exhibits. Visitors can enjoy panoramic views of Palma and its bay from the top of the castle while surrounded by fragrant pine woods.
name: Castell de Bellver
address: Carrer Camilo José Cela, s/n, Ponent, 07014 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: Vast shark tank & ocean habitats in aquarium with jungle micro-climate roof garden & guided tours.
detail_description: Palma Aquarium, located near the airport and opened in 2007, boasts the largest live coral collection in Europe. The aquarium features over 700 types of creatures, including impressive sand tiger sharks in the 'Big Blue' tank with three million liters of water. With more than 55 aquariums and 8000 fish from around the world, it offers an ideal family day out.
name: Palma Aquarium
address: Carrer de Manuela de los Herreros, 21, Platja de Palma, 07610 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: Vendors sell produce, cheese, seafood, pastries & prepared foods in a light-filled historic hall.
detail_description: Mercat de l’Olivar is Palma's largest covered market, conveniently located near the Placa d'Espanya and the main transport hub. The historic hall is filled with vendors selling a variety of goods, from produce and cheese to seafood and pastries. It has been open since the 1950s and offers an array of Balearic cheeses, fresh fruits and vegetables, Spanish olives, island salts, as well as takeaway Mallorcan meals.
name: Mercat de l’Olivar
address: Plaça de l'Olivar, s/n, Centre, 07002 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

detail_description: Galeria Plaza Mayor is an elegant square with beautiful colonnades, stretching from Calle San Miguel to Plaza Cort. The square features a stunning 600-year-old olive tree in front of the town hall, making it a popular spot for photo opportunities. During peak seasons, the narrow streets can get crowded, but it's still a charming place to explore and take in the local atmosphere.
name: Galeria plaza Mayor
address: Pl. Major, 3, Centre, 07002 Palma, Balearic Islands, Spain

excerpt: Part of Palma's Old Town area, La Seu brims with centuries-old landmarks, notably the sandstone Cathedral of Santa Maria of Palma (or La Seu Cathedral), one of Europe's tallest Gothic buildings. Close by, the 1300s Royal Palace of La Almudaina serves as the official residence of Spain's royal family when they visit Mallorca. Museu Diocesà displays Christian art and artifacts in the 13th-century Episcopal Palace.
detail_description: La Seu, located in Palma's Old Town, is a historic area filled with centuries-old landmarks. The standout attraction is the Cathedral of Santa Maria of Palma, also known as La Seu Cathedral, which is one of Europe's tallest Gothic buildings. Nearby, the Royal Palace of La Almudaina dates back to the 1300s and serves as the official residence for Spain's royal family during their visits to Mallorca.
name: La Seu
address: Centre, 07001 Palma, Balearic Islands, Spain

excerpt: Long, sandy strip on the Bay of Palma, popular for swimming & walking in view of Mallorca Cathedral.
detail_description: Platja de Can Pere Antoni is a long sandy beach located on the Bay of Palma, offering stunning views of Mallorca Cathedral. Despite its proximity to Palma, it remains relatively quiet and is easily accessible by public transport or bicycle. The beach is popular among locals and visitors alike for swimming, walking along the palm-tree-lined promenade, and soaking up the sun on its fine white sand.
name: Platja de Can Pere Antoni
address: Balearic Islands, Spain

excerpt: A beach resort by day, Playa de Palma transforms into a drinking and clubbing destination at night. Fringed by palm trees and a seafront promenade, it attracts families for swimming and water sports in the Bay of Palma, and water slides at Aqualand El Arenal. Chic hotels and gourmet restaurants are springing up among the souvenir shops, nightclubs, and themed bars popular with vacationers.
detail_description: Playa de Palma is a versatile destination that offers both relaxation and vibrant nightlife. During the day, families can enjoy swimming, water sports, and Aqualand El Arenal's water slides in the Bay of Palma. The seafront promenade is lined with palm trees and features chic hotels, gourmet restaurants, souvenir shops, nightclubs, and themed bars. At night, the area transforms into a lively party scene.
name: Platja de Palma
address: Palma, Balearic Islands, Spain

detail_description: Es Portixol is a charming coastal area located to the east, featuring a marina with inviting bars and cafes that offer picturesque terraces. Visitors can enjoy delectable meals at places like Sa Roqueta, known for its rich rice dishes such as fideua mulata and whole fish. The area boasts a long beach walkway perfect for leisurely strolls, lined with various bars, restaurants, and ice cream shops without an overload of touristy stores.
name: Es Portixol
address: Platja de Palma, Spain

excerpt: A tranquil garden surrounds the remains of these Arab baths from the time of Moorish rule.
detail_description: Banys Àrabs, also known as Arab Baths, is a historic site in Palma that offers a glimpse into the Islamic architecture of Majorca. Dating back to the 11th century, these baths are one of the few remaining examples of Moorish influence on the island. The construction of Banys Àrabs was a testament to Mallorca's cultural and commercial significance during that time.
name: Banys Àrabs
address: Carrer de Can Serra, 7, Centre, 07001 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

name: Palma Markets
address: Pg. del Born, 20, Distrito Centro, 07012 Palma, Balearic Islands, Spain

detail_description: Nestled in the charming Old Town of Palma de Mallorca, Old Town Tattoos is a must-visit for anyone looking to enhance their body art collection. This hygienic and beautifully designed studio boasts talented artists like Christian Otto and Stephen, who are not only skilled but also incredibly personable. Visitors rave about their experiences, whether it's getting a new tattoo or touching up an existing one. The atmosphere is friendly and welcoming, making it easy to strike up conversations while you get inked.
name: OLD TOWN TATTOOS
address: Carrer de Can Martí Feliu, 4, Centre, 07002 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

detail_description: Esglesia de Santa Eulalia, originally known as the Church of the Holy Cross, is a historic Gothic church in Palma. Construction on this original parish church began in 1335. The main entrance can be found at Carrer de Santa Creu 7.
name: Esglesia de Santa Eulalia
address: Distrito Centro, 07001 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: Quaint, narrow-gauge wooden train, dating to 1912, running along a scenic path from Sóller to Palma.
detail_description: Train Sóller Station, also known as Ferrocarril de Soller, is a historic narrow-gauge railway that has been operating since 1912. The charming wooden train takes passengers on a scenic 27km journey from Palma de Mallorca to the picturesque town of Sóller, nestled in a lush valley between mountains and the sea.
name: Train Sóller Station (Palma de Mallorca)
address: Carrer d'Eusebi Estada, 1, Nord, 07004 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: Moorish-style gardens, originally part of a royal palace, with ornate fountains & shady paths.
detail_description: S'Hort del Rei, also known as the Kings Gardens, is a charming Moorish-style garden located next to the Royal Palace of the Almudaina in Spain. Originally exclusive to the royal family, it was opened to the public after being remodeled in traditional Andalusian style in the 1960s. The gardens feature ornate fountains, shady paths, an archway dating back to Muslim times over a pond, and three sculptures by renowned artists.
name: L'Hort del Rei
address: Av. d'Antoni Maura, 18, Centre, 07001 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain

excerpt: Ornate Gothic edifice overlooking the sea, with a vast rose window & wrought-iron canopy by Gaudí.
detail_description: The Catedral-Basílica de Santa María de Mallorca, also known as La Seu, is a stunning Gothic edifice that overlooks the Mediterranean Sea. This architectural marvel was constructed over several centuries and showcases a blend of Moorish, Gothic, and Modernist influences. The cathedral features one of the largest rose windows in the world, known as the Gothic eye, which fills its interior with an ethereal light during morning hours.
name: Catedral-Basílica de Santa María de Mallorca
address: Plaça de la Seu, s/n, Centre, 07001 Palma, Illes Balears, Spain
